> [xcape2net](#comment_11_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): As far as anyone knows the FBI has compromised ALL publicly-available encryption and messaging programs.  The justified speculation is that is why the truecrypt people closed their company and gave their code to Veracrypt.  The only code that you can be sure doesn't have a backdoor is the code you write yourself.  I tried that myself , but  no one wants to use it, because it isn't zero knowledge.  I created a very simple message board that is encrypted with openssl, where the person who sends a message and the person who receives it are totally disconnected from each other, because there are no accounts.  Seems like this is what a lot of people would like to use, but they won't use it, because they don't trust me.  So, the only code you can trust to be uncompromised by the FBI or the programmer is code you write yourself.

This is not only about the crypt self.

1) it must by asynchronous. Code by public key of friend so only friend with his secret key can read.
And signed with own secret to show the friend own identity. Not any central signing !!! Just exchance between friends communicating together. Every has other secret/public key fror different communications!
2) komplicated alrgorythm on primary numbers.
3) Multichannel mix of meny crypted communications in a wide network area with meny routing points.
4) Nobody knows who write to who.

practical example

a mailing list
over this can every mail to the list
and every get every messages
so does nobody know, who write to who
only the right receiver can read a message for him
and nobody can know it who was it

> [xcape2net](#comment_13_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): I'm not exactly sure what you're asking, so I'll just describe the way my https (TLS 1.2)  message board website works.  First, there is no logging of anything except that the message itself is recorded along with a message number (randomly generated and unique to each message) and a password chosen by the user (must be > 11 characters, etc.).  The person who writes the message transmits the message number and password to the message receiver through any other method that he wants, which depends on how secure he wants his message to be.  The person who wants to read the message goes to the website and enters the message number and password to see the message.  So, there is no way for a third party to know who the message sender or receiver are or how to tie the two together.  The message is automatically deleted two weeks after is is recorded, whether it is read or not.  People, didn't like my system for a number of reasons which just come down to them not trusting me.
